questions.text: A study aims to compare the mean weight (in kilograms) of children diagnosed with severe protein-energy malnutrition before and after receiving a nutritional intervention program. Which type of statistical test is appropriate for analyzing the data in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Parametric only

Explanation :
The appropriate test in this scenario is the t-test, which is a parametric test. This test is suitable because it compares the means of quantitative data (weight in kilograms) and analyzes data from the same group of individuals (children with malnutrition)

questions.text: A researcher wants to compare the effectiveness of three different types of exercise programs on reducing blood pressure in individuals with hypertension. Which parametric test is most appropriate for analyzing the data?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) ANOVA

Explanation :


ANOVA is used to compare means in more than two different groups of individuals. Here, we have three different exercise groups and comparison is made on the effectiveness of these exercises on hypertension.

Parametric Test

Description

Paired Student's t-test

Used to compare means (± SD) in paired data from the same group of individuals before and after an intervention.

Unpaired Student's t-test

Used to compare means (± SD) in two different groups of individuals. The Z-test is a variant of the unpaired Student's t-test used when the sample size is > 30.

ANOVA

Used to compare means (± SD) in more than two different groups of individuals.

Pearson correlation coefficient

Measures the linear association between two variables and can range from -1 (perfect negative correlation) to +1 (perfect positive correlation).

 

Paired Student's t-test(Option A): Used when you compare two related groups (e.g., before and after in the same individuals). Not appropriate here — this study involves three independent groups.

Unpaired Student's t-test (Option B): Used to compare the means of two independent groups. Again, this study has three groups, so this test cannot be used.

Z-test (Option D) :Generally used when comparing means with known population variance or very large sample sizes. Not commonly used in this kind of study, especially when comparing more than two groups. Also, Z-tests are not ideal when comparing multiple group means — ANOVA is the standard.

questions.text: Which one of the following tests is used to study the association between the use of oral contraceptive pills (OCP) and breast cancer?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Chi-square test

Explanation :
Chi-Square Test is a non-parametric test used to study the association between two qualitative variables. In this scenario, breast cancer and OCP use are both qualitative variables.

questions.text:
A hospital administrator wants to determine if there is a significant association between the type of hospital ward (General, Intensive Care, and Pediatric) and the number of patients who experienced postoperative infections. The data collected over a month is as follows:

 


	
		
			
			Ward
			
			
			Patients with infections
			
			
			Patients without infections
			
			
			Total
			
		
		
			
			General
			
			
			20
			
			
			80
			
			
			100
			
		
		
			
			Intensive Care
			
			
			30
			
			
			70
			
			
			100
			
		
		
			
			Pediatric
			
			
			10
			
			
			90
			
			
			100
			
		
		
			
			Total
			
			
			60
			
			
			240
			
			
			300
			
		
	


 

Using the Chi-Square test, what is the expected number of patients with infections in the General Ward if there is no association between the ward type and infection status?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 20

Explanation:


The expected number for each cell in a Chi-square test is calculated by multiplying the row total by the column total and dividing by the grand total.

The formula for the expected frequency in a cell is: E=(Row Total)×(Column Total) / Grand Total

For the General ward and infections:

= (Total patients in General ward x Total patients with infections) / Total number of patients

= (100 x 60) / 300

= 6000 / 300

= 20

questions.text: What is this graphical representation of frequency of quantitative data called?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Histogram

Explanation:

Histogram:

  • It represents the frequency of continuous variables or quantitative variables.
  • Height is a quantitative or continuous variable (can take many possible values and also in between values)
  • It can be expressed in decimals and there is no gap in between.


 

Bar Diagram:

  • Simple bar diagrams represent the frequency of discrete variables like gender.
  • Discrete variables: These variables take fewer values and no in-between values.
    • Examples: Religion, Blood groups
    • These are not represented in decimals, so there are gaps.

 

Pictograph:

  • Used for graphical representation of qualitative variables
  • Used to teach something to a layman (illiterate).


 

Box and Whisker Plot:

  • A method of quantitative data representation.
  • Used to represent quartiles.
  • It comments on the type of distribution i.e., normal or skewed.
  • There is equal distribution on both sides (no outliers).
  • It is a normal distribution.
  • Tails are also equally distributed.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Component Bar Diagram

Here, the same bar has been divided into different components and each component represents its frequency. This is known as a component bar diagram.

Types of bar diagrams:

Image

Explanation

Simple Bar Diagram (Option A)
  • Simple bar diagrams represent the frequency of discrete variables like gender.

Compound Bar Diagram (Option B)

Component Bar Diagram (Option C)

Histogram (Option D)

  • It can be expressed in decimals and there is no gap in between.

questions.text: A teacher measured the heights of students in her class and wanted to visualize the distribution of these heights. She is considering using either a histogram or a frequency polygon for this purpose. Which of the following statements correctly distinguishes between a histogram and a frequency polygon?

choices.text: A histogram uses bars to represent frequencies of height intervals, while a frequency polygon uses dots connected by straight lines.
A histogram displays cumulative frequencies of student heights, whereas a frequency polygon displays individual height measurements.
A histogram can only display continuous data like heights, while a frequency polygon can only display categorical data.
A histogram provides a clearer representation of changes in student heights over time compared to a frequency polygon.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) A histogram uses bars to represent frequencies of height intervals, while a frequency polygon uses dots connected by straight lines.

Explanation:


Histogram:

  • It represents the frequency of continuous variables or quantitative variables.
  • Height is a quantitative or continuous variable (can take many possible values and also in between values)
  • It can be expressed in decimals and there is no gap in between.


 

Frequency Polygon:

  • It is drawn above a histogram.
  • Midpoints are joined by a straight line (frequency polygon).
  • Height is continuous (quantitative data).
  • If the number of observations is very large and group intervals are reduced, then the frequency polygon loses its angulature and becomes a curve, i.e., frequency curve.

Options B, C and D are incorrect because a histogram represents frequency of continuous variables or quantitative variables and a frequency polygon is drawn on top of it, connecting its mid-points by straight lines and they both have a similar accuracy in representation of changes in students’ heights over time.

questions.text: A clinic wants to analyze the cumulative number of patients who have completed a new vaccination program over the past year to evaluate the program's uptake and identify any trends in vaccination rates. Which type of graph should they use?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Ogive 

Explanation:
An ogive or cumulative frequency curve is useful for understanding how quantities accumulate over time. By plotting cumulative vaccination completion data on an ogive, the clinic can easily visualize the total number of patients vaccinated up to each month and observe trends in the rate of increase in vaccinations.

  • There is no dip or no fall of the curve.
  • Cases are constantly increasing

 

Fig. Ogive

 

A line chart (Option A) is used for showing trends of events or incidence of cases over time. It has both rise and fall.

Fig. Line chart


 

A pie chart (Option C) displays the proportions of different categories using slices of a circle.

  • Used to represent variables in percentages and proportions.
  • Represents qualitative variables.
  • Entire pie chart is 100%
  • Maximum divisions: 6 - 7 parts

Fig. Pie chart

 

A box plot (Option D) is used to show the distribution of data based on a five-number summary (minimum, first quartile (Q1), median, third quartile (Q3), and maximum).

  • It comments on the type of distribution, i.e., normal or skewed.

Fig. Box and Whiskerplot

questions.text:
A study is conducted to examine the relationship between hours of exercise per week and body mass index (BMI) among adults. Data from 30 participants are collected and plotted, with hours of exercise on the x-axis and BMI on the y-axis. The resulting scatter diagram is as shown below.



What type of correlation is depicted, and what is the correlation coefficient (r) value?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Negative correlation; r = -1

Explanation:


Scatter Diagram:

  • Represents correlation between two continuous variables i.e., association and direction of association.
  • Represented by correlation coefficient 'r'.
  • Value of 'r' ranges from: -1 < 0 < +1

 

Perfectly positive association:

Weight is increasing with the increase in height (perfectly linear association)

Value of r = +1

No association between x-axis and y-axis (r=0)

Perfectly negative association:

Variables on the x-axis increase with decreasing in the variables on the y-axis.

Value of r = -1

Possible values of r:

  • r = +1 (perfectly positive)
  • r ≥ 0.7 (Strong positive)
  • r = 0.4 to 0.6 (moderate positive)
  • r ≤ 0.3 (Weak positive)
  • r = -1 (perfectly negative)
  • r ≥ - 0.7 (Strong negative)
  • r = -0.4 to -0.6 (moderate negative)
  • r ≤ - 0.3 (weak negative)

questions.text:
A hospital conducted a study on the recovery times (in days) of patients after a specific surgical procedure. The data was summarized using a box and whisker plot as shown below:



Which of the following statements best describes the skewness of the recovery time data shown in the plot above?

choices.text: The data is both positively and negatively skewed.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) The data has no skewness.

Explanation:
In the given box and whisker plot, the right whisker is equal to the left whisker indicating Symmetrical distribution or no skewness.

  • It is used to show the distribution of data based on a five-number summary [minimum, first quartile (Q1), median, third quartile (Q3), and maximum].
  • It comments on the type of distribution i.e., normal or skewed.

Components of a Box and Whisker Plot:

  • Q1 - the lower edge of the box - denotes 25th percentile
  • Q3 - the upper edge of the box - denotes - 75th percentile
  • Q2 - Median - indicates the middle value of the dataset when arranged in ascending order.
  • The lower whisker (or left end) extends from the minimum data point up to Q1
  • The upper whisker (or right end) extends from Q3 to the maximum data point.

 

Interpretation of a Box and Whisker Plot:

  • Skewness: A longer whisker on one side suggests that the data is skewed towards that direction (positive skew for a longer right whisker, negative skew for a longer left whisker).
  • Central Tendency: The median (Q3) provides a measure of central tendency. Its position within the box indicates whether the data is symmetrically distributed around the median or skewed (long gap suggests skew in that direction).

 

Right skew (Option B):

i) Gap is more on the right side

ii) Rotate the image clockwise and interpret - gap on the right is longer - right sided skewness

Left skew (Negatively skewed): (Option C)

i) Gap is more on the left side - Mean

 

ii) Normal gap but left whisker is longer - left-sided skewness

 

Normal distribution: It represents symmetrically distributed data or that the data has no skewness (Option A)

i) Horizontal box

 

ii) Vertical box

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect about regression?

choices.text: It measures the strength and direction of the relationship between two or more variables.
It is used to predict the value of a dependent variable based on one or more independent variables.
Multiple Linear Regression describes the effect of multiple independent (Qualitative, Quantitative or Mixed) variables on dichotomous qualitative variables (discrete i.e., yes or no)
It can be linear or nonlinear depending on the relationship between variables.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Multiple Linear Regression describes the effect of multiple independent (Qualitative, Quantitative or Mixed) variables on dichotomous qualitative variables (discrete i.e., yes or no)

Explanation

Regression analysis is a statistical technique used to describe relationships between variables. It represents unitary change.

  • It quantifies how changes in one variable are associated with changes in another variable(s).
  • It provides insights into the direction (positive or negative correlation) and strength (the magnitude of the relationship) between variables. (Option A)
  • The process involves fitting a mathematical model to observed data to describe the effect of ≥1 independent variable on a dependent variable. (Option B)

Equation: y = a + bx

where, y = Dependent variable; a = Constant ; b = Regression coefficient ; x = Independent variable

E.g., Blood pressure is a continuous variable, it can be affected by age, cholesterol.

  • Regression analysis can be applied to both linear and nonlinear relationships between variables. (Option D)
  • Linear Regression describes the effect of one independent variable on a dependent variable (y = a + bx1 ).
  • Non-Linear Regression involves more complex mathematical forms, including logarithmic functions.

questions.text: Which of the following is an incorrect statement regarding sampling methods?

choices.text: In a probability sampling method, each individual in the representative population is provided with an equivalent likelihood of being included in the study.
Non-probability sampling includes convenience sampling, voluntary response sampling, purposive sampling, and snowball sampling.
As the size of the sample increases, sampling error decreases.
Cluster sampling is a type of Non-Random Non-Probability Sampling method.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Cluster sampling is a type of Non-Random Non-Probability Sampling method.

Explanation:

Cluster Sampling is a Random probability sampling method where the population is divided into clusters, and entire clusters are randomly selected to be included in the study. This method ensures that every individual has an equal chance of being included in the sample through random selection of clusters.

Sampling methods are of two types:-

  • Probability sampling methods- Each individual in the population has an equal chance of getting selected. (Option A)
  • Non-probability sampling methods- Not every member of the population has an equal chance of getting selected. It does not guarantee that the sample is representative of the population, thus can introduce bias.

 

Types of Sampling Method:

Random – Probability

Non-Random – Non-Probability (Option B)
  • Simple random sampling
  • Systematic random sampling
  • Stratified random sampling
  • Cluster random sampling
  • Multi-stage sampling
  • Multi-phase sampling
  • Convenient sampling
  • Purposive sampling
  • Quota sampling
  • Snowball sampling

 

Sampling Error:
Sampling error is the difference between the results obtained from a sample and the actual characteristics of the entire population. This type of error depends on:-

  • Sample Size: Generally, as the size of the sample increases, the sampling error decreases. (Option C)
  • Variability of Individual Readings: The natural variability or diversity within the population also affects sampling error

questions.text: Which of the following correctly defines Systematic Random Sampling?

choices.text: It involves selecting units from the population purely by chance, ensuring each unit has an equal probability of being chosen.
It involves selecting every nth unit from the population after a random starting point.
It involves systematically dividing the population into subgroups and randomly sampling from each subgroup.
It involves dividing the population into groups and randomly selecting entire groups to be included in the sample.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) It involves selecting every nth unit from the population after a random starting point.

Explanation:

Systematic Random Sampling is a type of Random Probability Sampling Method. It involves choosing every nth unit from the population after a randomly determined starting point, ensuring a systematic and uniform coverage of the population.

Random Probability Sampling Methods:

Sampling Method

Description

Example

Simple Random Sampling (Option A)

Selecting units purely by chance, ensuring each unit has an equal probability of being chosen.

Drawing names using random number generators or drawing lots.

Systematic Random Sampling

Selecting every nth unit from the population after a random starting point.

From a list of 1000 people and need a sample of 100, select every 10th person on the list after choosing a random starting point between 1 and 10.

Stratified Random Sampling (Option C)

Dividing the population into subgroups (strata) and randomly sampling from each subgroup.

Dividing a population into age groups (e.g., 18-29, 30-49, 50+) and randomly sampling individuals from each age group

Cluster Random Sampling (Option D)

Dividing the population into clusters and randomly selecting entire clusters to be included.

Dividing a city into neighborhoods (clusters) and randomly selecting a few neighborhoods. All residents in the selected neighborhoods are then included in the sample.

Multi-Stage Sampling

Combining several sampling methods in stages.

First, randomly select districts (simple random sampling), then within selected districts, randomly select schools (second stage), and finally, within selected schools, randomly select students (third stage)

questions.text: A researcher is conducting a study to estimate the prevalence of diabetes among patients with obesity. The researcher divides the patients into two gender groups (male and female) and then selects the study sample from each of these two groups separately. Which type of random probability sampling method is being used in this study?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Stratified Random Sampling

Explanation:

  • Stratified Random Sampling is the method used in this study. The researcher divides the population into subgroups (strata) based on gender and then selects random samples from each subgroup.

  • This approach ensures that both male and female patients are appropriately represented in the study, allowing for separate estimates of diabetes prevalence among the different gender groups.

 

Other Options:-

Option A - Simple Random Sampling involves selecting units from the population purely by chance without dividing the population into subgroups.

Option B - Systematic Random Sampling involves selecting every nth unit from the population after a random starting point, not dividing the population into subgroups.

Option D - Cluster Random Sampling involves dividing the population into clusters and then randomly selecting entire clusters, not stratifying by specific characteristics like gender.
